III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The facility must create and follow a uniform process for employee records to
ensure all the information required by licensing rules is in the employee's file,
especially at the time of the facility's annual audit. The electronic files provided by
HR were missing multiple documents. The HR file can come from the program
directly or HR, but the file provided must include all required documents.
2

• If orientation checklists are provided as verification, they must be filled out
completely with initials and dates of completion. The signature from the
supervisor at the bottom of the form is not sufficient.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request or require any consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility had one CAP as a result of their 2024 Renewal Audit and the CAP was
approved on 7/25/24. It should be noted during this renewal audit, the facility had
two different programs under the same license (TLC and Ridgeview), but TLC
opened their program under a new license as of 5/7/25. The facility was found in
violation of the following rules, however, all violations found were on TLC staff and
youth files.
- Rule 113(1)(e)
- Rule 113(1)(i) was a repeat violation.
- Rule 113(1)(j)
- Rule 114(1) was a repeat violation.
- Rule 128(3)
- Rule 155(1) was a repeat violation.
- Rule 156(1) was a repeat violation.
- Rule 166(1)(b-e) was a repeat violation.
The facility had one CAP as a result of SIR#2024SIC0001373 dated 5/13/24 with
a CAP approval date of 6/17/24. The facility was found in violation of Rule
159(1)(d) as it was found staff were not always completing their restraint refresher
trainings within 365 days of their previous training as required. The facility updated
their restraint policy to reflect the requirement, offered immediate CPI trainings
over the course of 1 week for staff who were overdue/nearing their due date,
required new hires to complete an online version of CPI orientation within 30 days
of hire, assigned CPI training to be completed within 90 days for new hires,
required seasoned staff to complete CPI training within 300 days from the date of
their last training, created a requirement for supervisors to review staff CPI training
dates, and scheduled ongoing quarterly CPI trainings to ensure opportunities for
continued compliance.
3

Financial Overview
The facility's 2025 financial budget and Bethany Christian Services' 2024 financial
audit were reviewed. There were no concerns noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
The MDHHS Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA) compliance monitoring report
was completed on 12/15/22 and the facility was found in compliance with all
standards. The facility also received a certificate of completion for compliance
monitoring for December 2022-December 2023. The facility had a compliance visit
in 2024, and they were found in compliance. Their next audit is scheduled for fall of
2025.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) noted staff turnover had a significant impact on the need
for the CAP from the 2024 Renewal Audit. Leadership staff left in TLC which
impacted other staff having history, knowledge of programming, procedures, and
why things are done in a certain manner/method. CA noted these same concerns
were not a part of the Ridgeview program, since TLC has now moved to a separate
license, these issues will not be problematic moving forward. CA noted an
additional position was put in place to help with training and quality assurance,
which has had a positive impact. CA noted the youth placed into the program are
demonstrating more chronic and complex mental health and behavioral needs, so
program assessments and evaluations are being completed to identify specific
areas to modify, including clinical programming (i.e. written work, methods of
intervention, adding additional clinical programming, etc.), behavioral programming
(i.e. adjusting behavioral system, program rules, day-to-day experiences, etc.), and
staff support (i.e. adding additional training and/or supports for staff). CA noted
Ridgeview Administration (residential director, clinical program director, and
program manager) conduct a monthly meeting to discuss program needs and
responses to those needs. In addition, Sanctuary Core Team Members conduct a
monthly meeting to discuss implementation of Sanctuary Model of Care Principles.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported they have not had any restraints at the facility for over three years,
which they're very proud of. Staff reported despite being short-staffed, everyone
(including therapists and administrators) is pitching in to pick up the slack, which is
proof of their teamwork. Staff reported communication is smooth and one of the
large perks of working at the facility. Staff reported regular team meetings are held,
which include great discussions amongst staff. Staff reported the program has
welcomed feedback more now than before, and the Sanctuary Program helps
facilitate that. Staff reported feeling valued and supported. Staff reported there
could always be more training for increased behaviors, different types of de-
escalation, etc. especially being short-staffed. Staff reported relationships between
staff and youth are good, and there have been no concerns regarding those
interactions. Staff reported there have been a lot of great changes happening
recently regarding new staffing positions opening, great & strategic choices for
4

promotions, etc. which makes everyone excited for the future. Staff reported they
feel the facility is building in ways for youth specialists to advance and become
more involved, which is going to increase their retention.
Youth reported things within the program and with school are going well. Youth
reported staff are nice and treat them well. Youth reported they like achieving their
levels in the program and feel supported in making progress. Youth reported staff
are quick to offer assistance when youth are struggling. Youth reported the only
time they don't feel safe in the program are when other youth act out, however, they
noted staff intervene quickly and efficiently. Youth reported the food is good and
they receive a sufficient amount of food. Youth reported other youth can be cruel
about joking about LGBTQ+, Autism, cancer, terrorism, racial issues, and any other
controversial topics. Youth reported they feel staff need to set firmer and more
consistent boundaries regarding what topics are appropriate to talk about and what
isn't because it can make youth feel unsafe, offended, etc. Youth reported they feel
all youth need more knowledge on Autism as a few youth admitted to the program
are on the Autism spectrum, so more information would be helpful in preventing
discrimination and harassment.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A tour of the facility occurred during the inspection on 6/18/25. The facility was
clean and in good condition. There were no safety concerns noted during the
inspection.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
